content.message:
Import analytical platform development account

Import the AP account to the MP, also bump the environments module to
allow ignoring of iam billing access which would force recreation of
account otherwise.
Add Cost Explorer Create Report permission for Data Engineers
Moves sqs to managed encryption. Adds additional statement to S3 KMS policy to allow use by SQS when receiving the notification payload.
Use cheaper and faster gp3 block storage for mirrorer.

Firehose configuration

We use Firehose as a means to buffer data from CSP reports into groups
written to S3, this means that a single S3 will likely contain multiple
CSP reports and be much more efficient to query than a single file per
report.

This firehose configuration expects a JSON put and it will output the
data into S3 after converting it to ORC file format.

The conversion to the ORC format was decided because using JSON produced
files that Athena could not query, as each JSON record didn't have a
separating new line. When confronted with this I decided that it was
better to convert the data into a format well suited for querying,
rather than say writing a lambda that adjusted the JSON.

I chose the ORC format over Paraquet as I found it easier to install
tools to view the files (installing parquet-tools is rather confusing as
brew has deprecated the package and I can't tell if it's actually
maintained), and then when I did get tools parquet didn't seem to like
the parquet format AWS uses with various warnings. Instead, using ORC was
quite straight forward and orc-tools was easy to install and use.

A pain point I found is that to create a Kinesis Delivery Stream I
needed to provide the Kinesis role with access to read Glue tables,
however the Kinesis role also needed permissions to run the created
Kinesis Delivery Stream. To resolve this cyclic dependency I split the
permissions into different resources.

Configure API Gateway

This sets up an API Gateway HTTP API as a proxy for the Lambda installed
in the previous commit.

This has a just single endpoint, POST /report, which integrates with the
aforementioned Lambda. As that Lambda has been configured for the 2.0
[1] payload this API gateway is configured to use that.

In order to call the Lambda we need to add a permission to the lambda
that permits invoking from the api-gateway.

I did wonder about configuring CORS headers for this - first as a means
to restrict the origins, second as a way to ensure success. However on
investigation I can't find any usage of CORS for browsers with
report-uri, so I believe browsers don't use it. It looks like it would
be needed should we switch to the upcoming Reporting API [2].

[1]: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/apigateway/latest/developerguide/http-api-develop-integrations-lambda.html#http-api-develop-integrations-lambda.proxy-format
[2]: https://developer.chrome.com/articles/reporting-api/#option-2-build-and-operate-your-own-report-collector

Remove UK Cloud VPN

This is no longer required because we've worked with Civica to allowlist the
IPs of our AWS NAT Gateways for the vast majority of their local authority
customers.

Additionally, UK Cloud is in liquidation and is being shut down. The
liquidators only expect the platform to be operational until 10 February 2023,
and in the meantime the liquidators have been increasing prices exponentially
to cover the costs of operating the platform with an ever diminished customer
base.

I have notified UK Cloud and the liquidators that from the end of December 2022
we no longer require our account.

Replicate assets bucket from prod to non-prod envs.

This replaces the sync_assets Jenkins cronjob (and is cheaper, more
reliable, uses less resources and works continuously instead of
nightly).

- govuk-assets-production replicates to staging and integration.
- govuk-assets-production still replicates to
  govuk-assets-backup-production as before.
- govuk-assets-backup-production keeps object versions indefinitely (but
  it's still not really a backup in the full sense; we should get Object
  Lock enabled on it and set a retention window).

Also update to AWS TF provider 5.
Update for cost filter

feat: Add the ability to declare multiple cost filters

* Use a dynamic block on 'cost_filters' to iterate over the list of objects. This way we can declare multiple filters.

BREAKING CHANGE: cost_filters variable is now a list of objects, not single object.
cost filters changes type
remove scaleway rdb (hosted in the cluster now, to save costs)
add hooks for cost_control
allow batch svc accounts to bill bandwidth to sandboxes

Scale down elastic search clusters (#1914)

* Scale down elastic search clusters

This is to reduce costs.
chore: switch test setup to use billing user (#801)
PAY-5797: Revert back to last known good commit
PAY-5797: Add Servicebus Premium
PAY-5797: Minor correction to default back to Standard sku
PAY-5797: Minor correction to prod.tfvars
containerInsights just cost me $5
pay per request + delete prot

Autoscale crater instances

Crater no longer requires each instance to be uniquely identified for
assigned crates to not be duplicated across instances, which means that we can
relatively directly just copy the stateless configuration into more instances.
This commit adds a CPU-based autoscaler to the GCP managed instance group, and
configures a systemd timer via the startup script which will update the
crater-agent on the instances.

This continues building upon the startup scripts rather than pursuing Ansible
automation (perhaps backed by Packer or so) because they're both pretty simple
and it doesn't seem worth the fairly high complexity cost Ansible and Packer
would bring at this time.

The current autoscaling is just so that in theory we shutdown instances during
idle periods (if we have them), but in practice that's likely more of an
opportunistic nice to have -- eventually it might allow us to burst up to finish
work much faster and then go idle, but in practice it's not clear whether we
want slow, but constant, or fast, but sometimes unavailable until the next
month. Something to continue thinking about.

Set up billing access for the Rust Foundation

Some members of the Rust Foundation need access to the billing portal on
the new account. This access has been granted using an AWS-managed
policy.

Invite legacy AWS account into organization

The legacy AWS account has been invited into the new AWS organization.
This enables us to access the account using SSO, and consolidates
billing for all AWS accounts.

Compress request logs from Fastly

Given the volume of traffic and logs, it seems prudent to compress the
logs to save on storage and bandwidth costs.

Use CloudFront functions for crates.io

Instead of using AWS Lambda functions to rewrite URLs, we are using
CloudFront functions which are simpler and cheaper.

Disable monitoring of Lambda functions

Datadog can monitor Lambda functions, but charges a fee for each
function. This is quite expensive for us, since every routing function
we use in CloudFront is globally distributed and is billed multiple
times (once per region).

For now, we are just going to disable the Lambda integration. Later, we
might want to enable it again, but add a tag and filter to selectively
monitor specific functions.

Remove billing access from legacy account

The staff of the Rust Foundation has access to the billing portal on
AWS, historically through the legacy account and now through the new
root account that consolidates billing. Instead of updating the custom
policy to remove deprecated policies, we are going to remove billing
access from the legacy altogether since it is no longer required.

Fixes #359
feat(CN-1605): Update KubeCost official Helm Chart to v1.99
feat(kubecost): Remove redundant parameters for RateCard
fix(kubecost): update core platform to customize scrape config
fix(kubecost): update scrape config PV/C labels, add FDI PV/C
feat(kubecost): allow propagation of kubecost configuration
fix(core-platform): kubecost helm config syntax
feat(core/kubecost): simplify configs.
feat(kubecost): update to 1.106.0 and and set the authenticated gateway annotation.

###
[`v4.49.0`](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-aws/blob/HEAD/CHANGELOG.md#​4490-January-5-2023)

[Compare
Source](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-aws/compare/v4.48.0...v4.49.0)

NOTES:

- resource/aws_dms_endpoint: For `s3_settings` `cdc_min_file_size`, AWS
changed the multiplier to kilobytes instead of megabytes. In other
words, prior to the change, a value of `32` represented 32 MiB. After
the change, a value of `32` represents 32 KB. Change your configuration
accordingly.
([#​28578](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-aws/issues/28578))
- resource/aws_fsx_ontap_storage_virtual_machine: The `subtype`
attribute is no longer deprecated
([#​28567](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-aws/issues/28567))

FEATURES:

- **New Data Source:** `aws_s3control_multi_region_access_point`
([#​28373](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-aws/issues/28373))

([#​28437](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-aws/issues/28437))

([#​28643](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-aws/issues/28643))

([#​28663](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-aws/issues/28663))

([#​28639](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-aws/issues/28639))

([#​28585](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-aws/issues/28585))

arguments in support of [asymmetric
keys](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/kms/latest/developerguide/symmetric-asymmetric.html)
([#​21054](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-aws/issues/21054))
- resource/aws_appflow_connector_profile: Add support for
`connector_type` CustomConnector. Add `cluster_identifier`,
`database_name`, and `data_api_role_arn` attributes for `redshift`

argument
([#​28420](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-aws/issues/28420))
- resource/aws_autoscaling_group: Add `desired_capacity_type` argument
([#​28658](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-aws/issues/28658))
- resource/aws_dms_endpoint: Change `s3_settings` `cdc_min_file_size`
default to 32000 in order to align with AWS's change from megabytes to

([#​28578](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-aws/issues/28578))
- resource/aws_ecs_service: Add `alarms` argument

- resource/aws_s3control_storage_lens_configuration: Add

NOTES:

- provider: This release includes an update to the AWS SDK for Go v2
with breaking type changes to several services: `finspace`, `kafka`,
`medialive`, `rds`, `s3control`, `timestreamwrite`, and `xray`. These
changes primarily affect how arguments with default values are
serialized for outbound requests, changing scalar types to pointers. See
[this AWS SDK for Go V2
issue](https://togithub.com/aws/aws-sdk-go-v2/issues/2162) for
additional context. The corresponding provider changes should make this
breakfix transparent to users, but as with any breaking change there is
the potential for missed edge cases. If errors are observed in the
impacted resources, please link to this dependency update pull request
in the bug report.
([#​34096](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-aws/issues/34096))

BREAKING CHANGES:

- data-source/aws_s3\_bucket_object: Following migration to [AWS SDK for
Go v2](https://aws.github.io/aws-sdk-go-v2/), the `metadata` attribute's
[keys](https://developer.hashicorp.com/terraform/language/expressions/types#maps-objects)
are always [returned in
lowercase](https://pkg.go.dev/github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go-v2/service/s3#HeadObjectOutput)
([#​33660](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-aws/issues/33660))
- data-source/aws_s3\_object: Following migration to [AWS SDK for Go
v2](https://aws.github.io/aws-sdk-go-v2/), the `metadata` attribute's
[keys](https://developer.hashicorp.com/terraform/language/expressions/types#maps-objects)
are always [returned in
lowercase](https://pkg.go.dev/github.com/aws/aws-sdk-go-v2/service/s3#HeadObjectOutput)
([#​33660](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-aws/issues/33660))

NOTES:

- data-source/aws_s3\_bucket_object: The `metadata` attribute's keys are
now always returned in lowercase. Please modify configurations as
necessary
([#​33660](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-aws/issues/33660))
- data-source/aws_s3\_object: The `metadata` attribute's keys are now
always returned in lowercase. Please modify configurations as necessary
([#​33660](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-aws/issues/33660))
- resource/aws_iam_\*: This release introduces additional validation of
IAM policy JSON arguments to detect duplicate keys. Previously,
arguments with duplicated keys resulted in all but one of the key values
being overwritten. Since this results in unexpected IAM policies being
submitted to AWS, we have updated the validation logic to error in these
cases. This may cause existing IAM policy arguments to fail validation,
however, those policies are likely not what was originally intended.
([#​33570](https://togithub.com/hashicorp/terraform-provider-aws/issues/33570))

fix: add subnets to allow 20+ nodes to run (#220)

prod is "DEGREADED" with only 19 nodes coming up due to

> Amazon AutoScaling was unable to launch instances because there are not enough free addresses in the subnet associated with your AutoScaling group(s).

so we add more subnets here.

Also prod is running with `desired_size: 20` so we up that here to match reality... and we dial down max_size as we dont want any suprise spikes in billing.

Switch to Flatcar Azure gen2 images and change worker type

* Switch from Azure Hypervisor generation 1 to generation 2
* Change default Azure `worker_type` from Standard_DS1_v2 to Standard_D2as_v5
  * Get 2 VCPU, 7 GiB, 12500Mbps (vs 1 VCPU, 3.5GiB, 750 Mbps)
  * Small increase in pay-as-you-go price ($53.29 -> $62.78)
  * Small increase in spot price ($5.64/mo -> $7.37/mo)
  * Change from Intel to AMD EPYC (`D2as_v5` cheaper than `D2s_v5`)

Notes: Azure makes you accept terms for each plan:

```
az vm image terms accept --publish kinvolk --offer flatcar-container-linux-free --plan stable-gen2
```

Rel:

* https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machines/dasv5-dadsv5-series#dasv5-series
* https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machines/dv2-dsv2-series#dsv2-series

Add Automatic Snapshot Volume Backups for Prometheus and Grafana

What
This enables the data for Prometheus, and the Grafana configuration to be
recovered if the volumes or instances are deleted. The snapshots are created
and managed using Amazon Data Lifecycle Manager, which incurs no extra cost
(https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/snapshot-lifecycle.html).

Why
It is best practice to have a backup of our data

Increase the memory available to the transfer_monitor_lambda

We've noticed this lambda failing through timeouts. Upon investigation it appeas the lambda has been conistently using its entire allocation of 128MB which suggested that it was insufficiciently resourced resulting in it locking up and timing out.

After experimentation is seems that 512MB is sufficient to cause the transfer lambda to succeed. This change will result in some increased cost but as this lambda runs quite infrequently the cost change is negligable.

Set scrape+eval intervals to 1m and increase retention.

1-minute sampling interval is perfectly adequate and allows us to retain
more history while making efficient use of resources.

Reduce Argo CD log verbosity and log as JSON.

Argo CD notifications-controller and repo-server are quite noisy at
`loglevel=info`. We don't need these info logs so let's not pay to store
them. This should help towards getting us back under our log quota in
LogIt.

Also set the log format to JSON so that the logs are easier to search.

Stop scraping kube-apiserver.

Turns out scraping the apiservers is surprisingly expensive and we're not
even using any of those metrics, so let's ditch it. This should make the
monitoring we do care about a bit more robust. We don't run the
apiservers anyway; that's in Amazon-land and there are metrics in
CloudWatch if we ever needed to look.

Switch to Flatcar Azure gen2 images and change worker type

* Switch from Azure Hypervisor generation 1 to generation 2
* Change default Azure `worker_type` from Standard_DS1_v2 to Standard_D2as_v5
  * Get 2 VCPU, 7 GiB, 12500Mbps (vs 1 VCPU, 3.5GiB, 750 Mbps)
  * Small increase in pay-as-you-go price ($53.29 -> $62.78)
  * Small increase in spot price ($5.64/mo -> $7.37/mo)
  * Change from Intel to AMD EPYC (`D2as_v5` cheaper than `D2s_v5`)

Notes: Azure makes you accept terms for each plan:

```
az vm image terms accept --publish kinvolk --offer flatcar-container-linux-free --plan stable-gen2
```

Rel:

* https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machines/dasv5-dadsv5-series#dasv5-series
* https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/virtual-machines/dv2-dsv2-series#dsv2-series
